div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin, Wednesday May 5th [1915]
div1.p: I was overjoyed to receive your first letter on my return from our advance point this morning. I took but four days from Paris, which is fairly quick. It was very sweet of your to write me at such length and to let me know how you’re getting along. Pretty soon you’ll be running the Ambulance and then I will have to look out, won’t I?
Now that we have evacuated after the first big fight we witnessed work is not very hard and I really have more time on my hands than you have down in quiet, remote Paris.

I suppose you have received (over)
most of the post cards I sent you. I have dispatched about a dozen to you at different times.

We have about a hundred and thirty German prisoners at our base now and have turned them into a “White Wings” gang to clean up the streets. Only one or two of them have hats on for the others had them taken from them and those fellow wear rags and things around their heads which gives them a ridiculous looking air. They are treated very well.

I wish I could tell you about the lay of the land around our advance point for it would make things so much more interesting for you and you could get the picture so much clearer. Its very eerie working out there
at night. Especially when one has to go to the farthest place de secour. No lights are allowed for fear of drawing the enemy’s fire. Even cigarettes are forbidden. It is almost impossible these dark nights to find one’s way. One creeps along, past sentinels who cry “Halte la!” and ask the pass word; past ^one long convoy after another, and through shadowy little groups of white walled houses. It is only when the dazzling illuminating shells mount into the sky over the long lines of trenches and light up the surrounding country that one can proceed with any speed. Often our batteries open fire in startling proximity to one and at first its quite a surprise. When one is so (over)
close the enemy’s shell do not have the warning whizzing sound, so unless one breaks near by its not a source of annoyance. If it should get you, you would never hear anything.

Last night a man was carried out to me that was dying. It was very dark and I could not see him well. I could hear his groans, tho [sic], all the way back. Finally he began to rat-a-tat-tat with his heels in spite of the fact that we had him lashed down and I thought he was passing. He lived at our base and wanted to be taken there to die. I told him I would take him there but when I went to the hospital for my papers the doctor said he wouldn’t last for the trip and sent him around to another
hospital.

We carry some dreadful cases. The other day even the French soldiers had to turn their heads away from the sight of one man. I would hate to think of you being out here and having to go through it. There are women Nurses at the hospital where we park our cars at our advance point and they are jealous of one another just as at Neuilly. Seems strange, for when its so very serious it should run as smoothly as possible. They do not know when a shell will kill them, however, and one has to admire their nerve for staying around.
It is remarkable tho [sic] with what composure the little city goes along. The shops are open, crowds are in the street and above the heavy roar of cannon one can hear the drone of school children going thru [sic] their lessons.

Our American friend Decker took us around yesterday to show us points of interest. We walked along one of the most beautiful tree lined and covered avenues I’ve ever seen. Then he took us by the rear way to his house. The approach started where a marmite had wrecked a wall and ended in the most exquisite, walled in little garden one could imagine. It was a perfect riot of color and the air was pungent with the delicious smell of flowers and blossoms. Decker introduced
us to a sweet old French lady who was sitting on a bench in front of a poppy bed. War seemed very remote in there— and then I noticed the old lady was patching up holes where bullets had torn a uniform. The contrast of all that is true of the whole town. The war is an every day affair and now reconciled to fitting in with the ways of peace. Of course its bad enough in the town but the chances of getting hit are few. Its when we go out to the different place [sic] de secour that we wonder if we’re coming
back, tho [sic] of course we don’t spend much time wondering.

Our squad is making good here every day and the French officials are well pleased. I am very comfortable and happy, tho [sic] being so far away from you and not having the pleasure of seeing and talking with you keeps me from being content. I have my diary with me and that helps, for I can read in it and call to mind the many many happy times I had with you.
Please give my sincerest regards to your mother and father and keep most of my affection for yourself. And do please write.
